newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-Coffee, hit by fund sell-off, dives 7 pct.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Coffee, hit by fund sell-off, dives 7 pct.

text.p: Robusta coffee futures took a sharp drop on Monday on a heavy sell-off by investment funds which analysts say was linked to weak technicals rather than supply/demand factors.
In one of the steepest losses in recent months, the benchmark May contract dived by 7.7 percent or $128 to the day's low of $1,535 a tonne before recovering slightly.
By the close, the contract was traded $123 lower at $1,540. The spot March position also posted triple-digit losses.
Monday's fall to the lowest level in nearly four weeks marked a sharp reversal from the recent blistering rally, which had lifted values by more than 50 percent since the start of 1997.
Heavy fund and speculative buying had propelled the rally as London chased a more spectacular bull run on New York's arabica futures.
But prices on both London and New York have started to come down since mid-March as the recent tight arabica supply situation showed signs of easing.
"Obviously, people turned negative quite quickly," said one analyst. "Sentiment has changed."
Traders said Monday's sharp descent in robusta was weighed down by fund long liquidation which was triggered by a weak chart outlook.
May broke the closely-watched $1,600 support early in the session and then moved lower quickly, triggering various stop-loss selling.
The market's recent sharp upward move had left many chart gaps unfilled.
Traders noted further downside potential but May could find some support at $1,502 on roaster demand.
Some funds were seen rolling forward their sizeable May positions further forward. May will become the spot month after March expires at the of this month.
Fundamentally, the robusta outlook has not changed much. Supplies are still ample and the market is bracing for the main Indonesian crop due to be shipped in the coming weeks.
But demand is consistent with roasters continuing to buy to meet fill-in demand.
The recent wide price difference between arabica and robusta has encouraged roasters to raise robusta usage for the lower-tier of the market.

The arbitrage has narrowed to around 91 cents a lb from a high of over 120 cents in the past weeks. But traders said it should narrow further to a more realistic 60 cent level. -- London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
